Women's cricket dismantle sorry Sheffield

25/04/2013

York's women's cricketers turned in an all round dominating performance yesterday as they beat their Sheffield opponents by 63 runs

Image by

By undefined undefined

UNIVERSITY OF YORK 125-8 SHEFFIELD UNIVERSITY 62 all out BUCS Northern Conference 1B
Images: Dave Goddin York's women's cricketers turned in an all round dominating performance yesterday as they beat their Sheffield opponents by 63 runs. A majestic batting performance from captain Louise Verroken Jones, who notched up an impressive 66 not out, and an equally impressive bowling effort from the whole team ensured that York secured their first official win in the club's history. After winning the toss, Sheffield elected to field first in the more favourable bowling conditions as the cloud cover was heavy and the wicket was slow. York's captain, Verroken Jones, and their vice captain, Anna Cook, opened the batting for a York side that was very different to that of last season. Both started in fine fashion with Jones getting off the mark with a glorious drive for four to the deep mid wicket boundary. Cook started her innings in a similar fashion, latching onto a poor Sheffield delivery and smashing it to the boundary. Neither Jones nor Cook appeared to be in any trouble against some tame opening bowling from Sheffield. It wasn't until the 7th over that Sheffield were able to make a break through; Cook misjudged a full, straight delivery and was bowled, ending an entertaining knock and reducing York to 31-1. Janet Sackey was next in for York, she played and missed at her first delivery but rotated the strike well to allow the in form Jones to continue playing with finesse. Sheffield struck again not long after, bowling Sackey for 1 in the 10th over and York now needed a partnership to compliment Jones' efforts. Katie Redgrave came in at number 4 and provided the anchor York needed for Jones to play around. Redgrave was exceptional in defence, stoically leaving anything that was headed wide and carefully playing anything that was legside and short. Jones continued to be an attacking presence, dispatching sort balls with contempt, and ensuring that York continued to tick along and maintain a decent run rate. Redgrave's resistance eventually ended in the 21st over and she was bowled for a watchful 6. The loss of Redgrave sparked a mini collapse for York as Beth Jakubowski and Diane Rigg were bowled in quick succession with full, straight deliveries from an impressive spell of Sheffield bowling. Kat Young arrived at the crease with York teetering at 85 for 5 and captain Jones precariously placed on 46 not out. Young provided balance to her captain's innings and defended determinedly to see Jones to a very accomplished 50. A tip of the bat to the applauding York team and a handshake were the only celebrations for Jones as she prepared to see out the remaining 5 overs. Young fell agonisingly close to seeing the innings through and Lorna Simmons was bowled for a duck, leaving Ella Caine with an over and three balls left to face. Caine got off the mark quickly with a calm push to short leg but was bowled shortly after by a good delivery from Sheffield's death bowler. It was left to Georgia Ridge to see out the final two deliveries and she proceeded to accompany her captain off the field who finished on 66 not out. York had achieved a highly competitive score of 125 for 8. York were tantalisingly close to the club's first ever victory as they took to the field for Sheffield's innings. Fresh from her batting heroics, Young opened the bowling; her first over was not quite on the money and she gave away several wides. At the opposite end, Georgia Ridge bowled an impressive maiden, troubling the batsman with her lengths and managing to get the ball to swing a little despite the now favourable batting conditions. York's breakthrough came in the third over; Young suddenly found a magical line and bowled a beauty to the Sheffield opener, Buttery, to remove her for a duck. She struck in the fifth over as well, removing fellow opener Boughton and allowing Jones to snaffle a catch at gully to give Young her second wicket. Ridge was not to be left out though; she bowled Sheffield's Fitzpatrick for a duck, a just reward for a fantastic spell of seam bowling. Sheffield were left reeling at 14 for 3. Young finished tearing through Sheffield's top order with another wicket and finished her spell with 3 for 17. Replacing Ridge, Beth Jakubowski started her spell with a strong LBW shout that was turned down as Sheffield progressed to 33 for 4. The slow, low wicket suddenly came alive for York's spinners, Jones came on to take a brilliant caught and bowled, reducing Sheffield to 36-5 and soon after took a second wicket to bowl Park for 6. York were on fire and Cook came on to baffle Sheffield with her leg spin and bowled Rogers with ease. It was Jones and Redgrave who then took a further two wickets with Jones bowling Groves and Redgrave bowling Lee after a very skilful over. Sheffield were now staring into the abyss at 62 for 9. It was Cook who finished off proceedings, Sheffield's number 11 Harrison gifted a simple catch to Redgrave and Sheffield were all out for 62. It sparked wild celebrations amongst the York team, who despite inexperience proved that their side certainly has talent. An ecstatic captain Jones said after the match, "I'm so proud of everyone, everyone applied themselves, everyone did what I asked them and I think we really showed that we're ready for Roses and that's a great win right before the most important game of the season." When asked how she felt about being the first winning captain she said, "I'm over the moon, I didn't want to get too excited when we were at tea but I knew we had it, we were looking strong. Everyone did their best and everyone contributed, it wasn't a one horse race, I hope everyone enjoyed it and I'm really proud of everyone." Player of the Match: Louise Verroken Jones
